OK, first reactions: Good production values, looks beautiful, a little slow (hope that gets better after all the exposition,) lots of naked women and boobies, and it has promise.
Nevermind.
this has been utterly uninteresting thus far
I thought it was a lot of fun, but having read the books, I was just in it for the experience
But it started to pick up near the end
It really did move slow
I'll give it some more time
They did cover a lot in the first episode, but I think that was mostly to get people who haven't watched the series interested and give them a few "oh snaps".
I really enjoyed it - hard to compare to books (there's just so much going on), but I thought it captured the series well (so far).
Are you not entertained?
good enough to watch more for sure
I thought it was good
it's def gonna get cancelled
I loved it. There's a lot of major characters to introduce in a single episode, my bet is that it'll be easier to follow in upcoming episodes.
It was totally awesome. But those who haven't read books may think it's kinda boring - but they don't know how epic the story will get! This episode was just introducing.
That's good news. Gives it time to really get rolling.
@leah Yep. Casting is really fitting (Tyrion - the Imp - rulez). And I'm glad HBO already renewed second season.
@Snipsley the episode ending was pretty crazy though
Watched it again today. Sure, there's a whole bunch of characters being introduced making the pace a bit slow, but it should really pick up in the next few episodes.
so what's the major criticism (besides "it's slow")?

The characters all sort of blurred together.  Characters actions all seemed to be arbitrary.  The only person whose characters were distinct was the blonde prince fellow and the arrogant character that pushes the boy out the window. Character introductions are important for people who don't have context (ie haven't read the book)  I think they did not do a good job at this.

@thauber Can't disagree more. I think they did pretty good job at this - Robert is fat drunk, lord Stark is honourable man, lady Stark careful mother and their kids are exactly the same as in the book. Lannisters couldn't be acted better, Danerys is scared, her brother wants his throne back for every cost (as everybody else)... wow, there's a lot of characters here. And they had to introduce them in one hour - this couldn't be done better. :)

@Snipsley The fact that they had a lot of characters to introduce doesn't buy them any sympathies. If they have to introduce 100 characters in the first show and you don't do a good job of it, its still bad story telling.  You guys have read the books you know the characters and that is making you see characters that haven't developed in the show yet.  The problem is half those names that you listed off I don't even know.  It's because they spent the first episode showing a glimpse of 100 charcters instead of really focusing on 5 and introducing them well.  Compare it to the wire, that had a lot of characters.  You watch the first episode, and the characters are memorable and you already start to know them.  And if you say that I can't compare it to the wire because thats not fair, well to that I would respond that they attempted to tell a story with an intricate web of characters, so they can be held accountable when they do it poorly.  I'm still going to watch the show, but reading the books shouldn't be a prerequisite.  I've also heard that critics have said that the first episode is the worst of the first 6.

@thauber I understand you. In my opinion, the introducing was well done - but yeah, maybe I am little blinded by knowing all characters already. People around me didn't read the saga and still loved it though.

One thing I did notice is that you really had to pay attention to understand what was going on -- something I like in a show (like west wing). I could see that as being interpreted as light on details.
Man, I still have not watched this. I am so far behind.
